text: If you cannot find Christ in the beggar at the church door, you will not find Him in the chalice.
author: St. John Chrysostom

text: The soul is dyed the color of its thoughts. Think only on those things that are in line with your principles and can bear the light of day.
author: St. Basil the Great

text: It is not he who begins well who is perfect. It is he who ends well who is approved in God's sight.
author: St. Basil the Great

text: Prayer is the place of refuge for every worry, a foundation for cheerfulness, a source of constant happiness, a protection against sadness.
author: St. John Chrysostom

text: The proof of love is in the works. Where love exists, it works great things. But when it ceases to act, it ceases to exist.
author: St. Gregory the Great

text: Acquire the spirit of peace, and a thousand souls around you will be saved.
author: St. Seraphim of Sarov

text: The goal of our life is union with God. The way to that union is prayer. The foundation of prayer is humility.
author: St. Theophan the Recluse

text: Do not be surprised that you fall every day; do not give up, but stand your ground courageously. And assuredly, the angel who guards you will honour your patience.
author: St. John Climacus

text: If we truly love God, we shall have a great desire for the life to come, and that desire will set us free from earthly affections.
author: St. Maximos the Confessor

text: The chief thing is not to think too much but to love much, and so do whatever best awakens you to love.
author: Elder Paisios of Mount Athos

text: God has promised forgiveness to your repentance, but He has not promised tomorrow to your procrastination.
author: St. Augustine of Hippo

text: We are to love God for Himself, because of a twofold reason: nothing is more reasonable, nothing more profitable.
author: St. Bernard of Clairvaux

text: Silence is the cross on which we must crucify our ego.
author: St. Seraphim of Sarov

text: A Christian is a living sermon, whether or not he preaches a word.
author: St. Gregory the Theologian

text: In the same way that a small fire can set ablaze a great forest, so the remembrance of a single wrong can destroy all our virtues.
author: St. John Cassian

text: Let us not seek the easy way. Christ did not seek the easy way.
author: St. Porphyrios of Kavsokalyvia

text: Be the bee of the Church. A bee collects honey from every flower; take what is good from everywhere.
author: Elder Paisios of Mount Athos

text: The present life is a school, a school where we learn to know God. He who knows God most, he is the wisest of all.
author: St. John Chrysostom

text: You will find something far greater in the woods than in books. Trees and stones will teach you that which you cannot learn from masters.
author: St. Isaac the Syrian

text: Through patience and the comfort of the Scriptures we might have hope.
author: The Apostle Paul

text: No one can be at the same time very merciful and very severe. You must choose one or the other: either love sinners or hate the wicked.
author: St. John Chrysostom

text: Suffering is a gift. In it is hidden mercy.
author: St. John Chrysostom

text: He who does not pray is deprived of communion with God.
author: St. John Chrysostom

text: Fasting is a medicine. But medicine, as beneficial as it may be, becomes useless if the patient does not know how to use it.
author: St. John Chrysostom

text: A tree is known by its fruit; a man by his deeds. A good deed is never lost; he who sows courtesy reaps friendship, and he who plants kindness gathers love.
author: St. Basil the Great

text: When you are praying, do not shape within yourself any image of the Deity, and do not let your mind be stamped with the impress of any form; but approach the Immaterial in an immaterial manner.
author: St. Basil the Great

text: Strive to enter through the narrow door of fasting. As a wide river becomes narrow when enclosed by a dam, so the soul is compressed by fasting and becomes concentrated.
author: St. Basil the Great

text: The Holy Spirit is not given in a measured portion, but floods the soul of the believer entirely.
author: St. Gregory the Theologian

text: If you are a theologian, you will pray truly. And if you pray truly, you are a theologian.
author: St. Gregory the Theologian

text: Let us become like Christ, since Christ became like us. Let us become gods for His sake, since He became man for our sake.
author: St. Gregory the Theologian

text: This world is a sea in which we are drowning, but the cross of Christ is the bridge by which we cross over to the other shore.
author: St. Isaac the Syrian

text: Be at peace with your own soul, then heaven and earth will be at peace with you.
author: St. Isaac the Syrian

text: Whoever has attained the knowledge of his own weakness has reached the summit of humility.
author: St. Isaac the Syrian

text: Love is the fruit of prayer. He who is diligent in prayer shall come to possess love.
author: St. Maximos the Confessor

text: He who does not yet have the love of God does not yet truly believe in God.
author: St. Maximos the Confessor

text: I know that God is everywhere present and that He fills all things, yet I dare to say that He is more especially present in the hearts of those who love Him.
author: St. Symeon the New Theologian

text: The person who has come to know the weakness of human nature has gained experience of divine power, and such a person never belittles anyone.
author: St. Symeon the New Theologian

text: We do not worship matter, but the Creator of matter, who for our sake became material and deigned to dwell in matter, and through matter effected our salvation.
author: St. John of Damascus

text: If you desire the true and eternal life, hope for it not from a tree or herb or bird, but from God who created all these things.
author: St. John of Damascus
source: An Exact Exposition of the Orthodox Faith

text: Place your mind before the mirror of eternity; place your soul in the brightness of glory. And transform your entire being into the image of the Godhead itself.
author: St. Ephrem the Syrian

text: Virtues are formed by prayer. Prayer preserves temperance, suppresses anger, restrains pride, cleanses from malice, and heals cruelty.
author: St. Ephrem the Syrian

text: The heart itself is but a small vessel, yet dragons are there, and lions; there are poisonous beasts and all the treasures of evil. But there, too, is God, the angels, the life, and the kingdom.
author: St. Macarius the Great

text: As the eyes of the body see earthly things, so the eyes of faith see heavenly ones.
author: St. Macarius the Great

text: Keep your mind in hell, and despair not.
author: St. Silouan the Athonite

text: The Lord loves all people, but He gives grace only to those who are humble.
author: St. Silouan the Athonite

text: We must pray for all people as for ourselves. The Lord commanded us to love our enemies, and to pray for those who hurt us.
author: St. Silouan the Athonite

text: When someone is full of the Holy Spirit, he cannot contain his joy, even though he has no possessions.
author: Elder Paisios of Mount Athos

text: If you have love in your heart, you see everything differently. You see the good side of everything.
author: Elder Paisios of Mount Athos

text: God always gives us what we need, not what we want. What we want may harm us; what He gives always helps us.
author: Elder Paisios of Mount Athos

text: He who has renounced all things and acquired humility of heart has found the treasure of treasures.
author: St. Ignatius Brianchaninov

text: True repentance consists not only in turning from sin, but in acquiring the virtues opposite to those sins which we have committed.
author: St. Ignatius Brianchaninov

text: Be kind, be loving, be forgiving, be generous to one another. Everything in this life passes away — only God remains, only He is worth struggling towards.
author: St. Nikolai Velimirovich

text: Bless my enemies, O Lord. Even I bless them and do not curse them. They have driven me into Thy embrace more than my friends have.
author: St. Nikolai Velimirovich

text: True happiness is found only in God. It cannot be found in wealth, for that leads to avarice; nor in knowledge, for that leads to pride; nor in glory, for that leads to vanity.
author: St. Nektarios of Aegina

text: Christ is everything. He is joy, He is life, He is light. Christ is everything. He is the true light that makes man joyful.
author: St. Porphyrios of Kavsokalyvia

text: Do not fight to expel the darkness from the chamber of your soul. Open a tiny aperture for light to enter, and the darkness will disappear.
author: St. Porphyrios of Kavsokalyvia

text: Prayer is like a spring of water. The more you draw from it, the more it flows.
author: St. John of Kronstadt

text: Live as though every day is your last, and God will give you many more.
author: St. John of Kronstadt

text: Where humility is, there also is wisdom. Where there is no humility, there also is no wisdom, but only vain opinion.
author: St. Tikhon of Zadonsk

text: A brother asked Abba Moses for advice. The old man said: Go and sit in your cell, and your cell will teach you everything.
author: Abba Moses

text: Abba Anthony said: I no longer fear God, but I love Him. For love casts out fear.
author: Abba Anthony the Great

text: An elder said: Cut off from yourself the desire to love many things, and in this way your mind will not be scattered but will be gathered to the one thing needful.
author: The Desert Fathers
